column4: A dataset which ignores a critical population is liable to come to conclusions that might harm that population.

column3: Aggregates might become inaccurate, impeding all comparisons
column4: Faulty data can cause aggregates to be inaccurate, or at least different from the user intuition.

column3: Aggregates might become inaccurate, impeding all comparisons
column4: Outliers can cause upstream failures if not addressed properly by wrecking the visual scale and warping the perception of the real distribution.
column7: Can affect ability to read aggregate visualization accurately

column4: Data may be cherry picked, as a non-representative sample, or may not be robust enough to accurately backup the rendered claim in the visualization.
column7: Cairo's new book

column4: Differently spelled groups can cause rows to mis-aggregate, causing inaccurate comparisons.
Marks assumed to represent single values might represent several (which may then be further skewed by aggregates like SUM).
column7: assumed singular values may be aggregated. Example: making a line chart of year has data from 1.5 years. Users assumes each mark indicates ONE measurement, when in fact their might be several

column4: Visualization might show a strong relationship between variables, when in fact that relationship is part of the data composition (eg A+B = C, plot A vs C).
column7: Uni-Detect: A Unified Approach to Automated Error Detection in Tables

column4: Apparent trends might be attributed to the more specific/recently specified filters rather than relatively "simpler" explanations.

column2: For more see Kim etals Dirty Data Taxonomy
Differing Number of Records by Group
column3: Aggregate may be perceived as having a common cardinality
column4: Marks assumed to represent consistent number of values might have a variable number of entries, which can mask missing data or can lead to incorrect assumptions about aggregates.
column7: A mismatch in row cardinality (world indicators example)

column3: Observed trend reverses when aggregation changes
column4: An observed trends reverses when the aggregation level changes.
Filtering down to an uncharacteristic subset offers an incorrect distribution.
column7: e.g. the chart filters out to only a tiny subset of data where something is true. data loom: law of small numbers (cherry picking, bias sample fallacy)

column3: Real trend is made invisible
column4: The magnitude of a real trend might be nullified or made invisible, causing the reader to miss a real data trend.
column7: SLIGHTLY UNSURE ABOUT CLASSIFICATION

column4: Correlation is not robust to slight changes in the data, which may give the impression of a non-extant correlation.
column7: Correlation is not robust to slight changes in the data

column3: Irrelevant conclusions could be made
column4: A high variability or noise in can mask the real information being presented, causing readers to identify non-existent trends.

column3: Gives the impression of an non-extant correlation
column4: Spurious difference (due to p-hacking, say. or just un-communicated sampling variability) can give the impression of non-extant correlation.
column7: Spurious difference (due to p-hacking, say. or just un-communicated sampling variability)

column2: Outliers Combined with Wrong Aggregation Type
column4: Using extremal aggregates (such as min/max) will likely cause misinterpretation of bars as readers tend to assume bars show sums. (I THINK THIS WHAT WITHIN BAR SAYS)

column3: Two things may appear to be equal when in fact their distributions are fundamentally different
column4: Second order statistics often carry critical information about the variance or distribution, which is masked through simple central tendencies.

column3: Apparent trend will be the aliases rather than the signal

Multiple distinct data classes presented as the same can cause errors in the inference of trends.
column7: Automatic Selection of Partitioning Variables for Small Multiple Displays,related to simpson's paradox

column4: Visualizations being used as decoration (rather than a mapping between data and image) prey on the readers assumption that the chart is being used as normal.

column3: Trend can appear from flat data or vice-versa
column4: Not using an appropriate aspect ratio can cause trends to be hallucinated in otherwise trend-free data.
column7: HEER PAPER. Mirages can be perceptual in nature, but are driven by a decision somewhere in the analytics pipeline. The knob that controls this mirage is charts dimensions

column4: Area encoded marks can be misunderstood as encoding length or area, which will describe different magnitudes of meaning (though consistent ordinal meaning).
column7: e.g. “the incredible shrinking doctor”

column3: Reader mistakes one group for another
column4: Readers may mistake one data class for another.
Readers expect time to progress in the same direction as their language, reversing convention can cause reversed interpretation.

column4: Aggregate marks with no opacity overlapping each other do an implicit max, as shown in \figref{fig:opacity-permute}.

column3: Trend understood to be opposite

column4: Can cause readers to inaccurately correlate variables and cluster values.

column3: Can cause sorting errors and errors in characterizing distribution

column4: Irregular or uintutive binning may negatively affect interpretation of bin meaning.

column4: Reader may misinterpret color on a map as indicating the content of that region rather than a data variable, for instance green being interpreted as indicating forests and blue indicating ocean.
column7: Green or blue map regions can lead the reader to believe that those regions posses semantically meaningful trends (forest/ocean respectively). CITATION NEEDED, maybe Selecting Semantically‐Resonant Colors for Data Visualization

column3: Readers misunderstand variability
column4: Bar charts that have variability are frequently misunderstood.
column7: Bar graphs depicting averages are perceptually misinterpreted: The within-the-bar bias

column4: Over highlighting outliers can mask important data features, however so can ignoring them.
Chosen domain hides outliers, impending the reader from accurate extrema detection.
column7: specified domain removes significant outliers, may be the same as cherry picking

column4: Reader may hallucinate a trend based on the rendered ordering.
column7: Eg Line chart across nominal data. Citation VisLint

column4: Related to "area/length mismatches" a mark might be encoded as big/medium/small which readers might then read as quantitative.

column3: Purported insight not robust to minor changes
column4: Visualization includes arbitrary choices made by the designer that causes reader to hallucinate un-meaningful inferences. The modifiable areal unit problem is an example of this problem.
Non-data parameter can mask a critical data error, such as a histogram binning hiding a missing value.
